title: How to Make Celery Juice

steps.headline: Cut off the top leaves and the base from 1 bunch of celery.
steps.description: Lay 1 bunch of celery sideways on a cutting board. Use a sharp kitchen knife to carefully cut off the top leafy parts and the white base that connects the stalks at the bottom.Tip: Try to get organic celery if you can. This will ensure the celery has not been sprayed with any pesticides or other agricultural chemicals. A bunch of celery typically contains about 8-9 individual celery stalks. Advocates of celery juice suggest drinking a glass of it in the morning on an empty stomach, although there is no research that shows this is any better than consuming it at any other time of the day.

steps.headline: Rinse each stalk of celery separately to thoroughly clean them.
steps.description: Hold a stalk of celery under a running tap and gently rub your fingers along it to remove dirt and any other substances. Repeat this for each stalk to clean them all. You can also put the stalks in a colander, if you have one that is big enough, and rinse them all at once.

steps.headline: Put the stalks of celery one at a time through the feeding tube of a juicer.
steps.description: Turn on your juicer and put 1 stalk of celery into the feeding tube. Push it gently through, using the pushing stick as needed, and repeat this for each stalk of celery. If your juicer doesn’t have a built-in receptacle, then make sure to place a jug or glass underneath the spout before you start juicing.

steps.headline: Serve the juice immediately.
steps.description: Pour the juice in a glass and drink up. Celery juice on its own isn’t very tasty, so chug it if you want to get it over with. If you don’t want to drink all the juice at once, you can store leftovers in a sealed container in the fridge for up to 24 hours. Something like a mason jar works best.

methods.name: Making Celery Juice in a Blender

steps.headline: Cut 2 bunches of celery stalks up into 1 in (2.5 cm) chunks.
steps.description: Lay 1 bunch of celery sideways on a cutting board and cut off the leafy tops and the white bottom. Cut the celery stalks into approximately 1 in (2.5 cm) chunks and repeat the process for another bunch of celery. It takes twice as much celery to make a serving of celery juice in a blender than a juicer because you will be left with a lot more fiber at the end that you need to strain out.

steps.headline: Wash the celery pieces in a colander to clean them.
steps.description: Put the chopped celery into a colander. Hold it under running water and move the pieces around with your hand to wash any dirt and other substances off. This is especially important if you are using non-organic celery to make sure you remove any traces of pesticides or other chemicals. Try to use organic celery for making juice whenever possible.

steps.headline: Blend about 1/4 of the celery pieces until they are roughly chopped.
steps.description: Place about 1/4 of the chopped celery stalks into the base of a high-speed blender and put the lid on. Turn the blender on at medium to high speed until the celery pieces are chopped into smaller pieces and start to release liquid. This helps the blender get going so it will be easier to blend the rest of the celery. If you try to blend it all at once, it will be much harder to get an even, smooth consistency.

steps.headline: Put the rest of the pieces in and blend the celery until it is smooth.
steps.description: Take the lid of the blender off and add the rest of the chopped celery on top of the celery you started to blend. Put the lid back on and blend the celery at high speed until it is a smooth, juice-like consistency.Tip: Pour 1/4-1/2 cup (59-118 mL) of water into the blender if you are having trouble blending the celery to help it get going. Use the push stick, if your blender has one, or another utensil to push chunks of celery down towards the blades as you blend them. Be careful not to get the utensil caught in the blades if you are using something long enough to reach them.

steps.headline: Strain the celery juice through a nut milk bag.
steps.description: Place a nut milk bag in a measuring cup or pitcher and pour the blended celery in. Lift up the bag and squeeze it hard with your hands to strain all the liquid through into the container. Discard the pulp inside the bag. A nut milk bag is a fabric bag that is normally used for straining out the pulp of nuts to make nut milks, such as almond milk or cashew milk. They also work perfectly for straining blended juices. If you don’t have a nut milk bag, you can strain the juice through a fine-mesh colander or cheesecloth instead. Keep in mind that if you use a colander you won’t be able to squeeze as much of the juice out this way, so there will be more waste.

steps.headline: Serve the juice right away.
steps.description: Pour the strained juice into a cup of your choice. Drink the juice immediately for the freshest taste. You can store leftover juice in a mason jar or other sealed container for up to 24 hours in the fridge.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 cup (110 g) of chopped pineapple for a tropical twist.
steps.description: The pineapple will make the juice sweeter and add more vitamins and nutrients. Juice or blend chopped fresh pineapple with the celery to make this tropical variation. You can use frozen pineapple chunks or canned pineapple instead of fresh pineapple. If you use canned pineapple, you can even add a bit of the juice from the can in for extra flavor. If you're using a blender, the extra moisture can make blending easier!

steps.headline: Put in 1/4 cup (5 g) of fresh mint leaves for a minty-fresh juice.
steps.description: Juice or blend the leaves with the celery to combine them and make this minty variety of celery juice. Mint also helps aid healthy digestion, which is one of the benefits that celery juice is said to have. An added bonus of fresh mint leaves is that the juice will help freshen your breath!

steps.headline: Mix in 2  tsp (9.9 mL) of lemon juice for a celery lemonade.
steps.description: Stir in freshly-squeezed lemon juice to your celery juice to boost the flavor and add some vitamin C. Add more or less based on your personal tastes. You can substitute lime for lemon juice if you like.

steps.headline: Combine the celery with 1 chopped apple to make celery-apple juice.
steps.description: Remove the core and chop up 1 apple of a variety of your choosing. Put the chunks through your juicer or in your blender with the celery when you are making your juice.Tip: You can combine any number of ingredients you would like to create your own celery juice recipe. Other things you can try include ginger, kale, cucumber, and carrots. Granny Smith apples are a good choice because their slightly sour flavor helps hide the bland flavor of the celery.

Use a sharp kitchen knife to carefully cut off the top leafy parts and the white base that connects the stalks at the bottom.Tip: Try to get organic celery if you can. This will ensure the celery has not been sprayed with any pesticides or other agricultural chemicals. A bunch of celery typically contains about 8-9 individual celery stalks. Repeat this for each stalk to clean them all. You can also put the stalks in a colander, if you have one that is big enough, and rinse them all at once. Put the stalks of celery one at a time through the feeding tube of a juicer. Turn on your juicer and put 1 stalk of celery into the feeding tube. Push it gently through, using the pushing stick as needed, and repeat this for each stalk of celery. If your juicer doesn’t have a built-in receptacle, then make sure to place a jug or glass underneath the spout before you start juicing. Serve the juice immediately. Pour the juice in a glass and drink up. Celery juice on its own isn’t very tasty, so chug it if you want to get it over with. If you don’t want to drink all the juice at once, you can store leftovers in a sealed container in the fridge for up to 24 hours. Something like a mason jar works best. It takes twice as much celery to make a serving of celery juice in a blender than a juicer because you will be left with a lot more fiber at the end that you need to strain out. Wash the celery pieces in a colander to clean them. Put the chopped celery into a colander. Hold it under running water and move the pieces around with your hand to wash any dirt and other substances off. This is especially important if you are using non-organic celery to make sure you remove any traces of pesticides or other chemicals. Try to use organic celery for making juice whenever possible. Blend about 1/4 of the celery pieces until they are roughly chopped. Place about 1/4 of the chopped celery stalks into the base of a high-speed blender and put the lid on. Turn the blender on at medium to high speed until the celery pieces are chopped into smaller pieces and start to release liquid. This helps the blender get going so it will be easier to blend the rest of the celery. If you try to blend it all at once, it will be much harder to get an even, smooth consistency. Put the rest of the pieces in and blend the celery until it is smooth. Take the lid of the blender off and add the rest of the chopped celery on top of the celery you started to blend. Use the push stick, if your blender has one, or another utensil to push chunks of celery down towards the blades as you blend them. Be careful not to get the utensil caught in the blades if you are using something long enough to reach them. Strain the celery juice through a nut milk bag. Place a nut milk bag in a measuring cup or pitcher and pour the blended celery in. Lift up the bag and squeeze it hard with your hands to strain all the liquid through into the container. They also work perfectly for straining blended juices. If you don’t have a nut milk bag, you can strain the juice through a fine-mesh colander or cheesecloth instead. Keep in mind that if you use a colander you won’t be able to squeeze as much of the juice out this way, so there will be more waste. Serve the juice right away. Pour the strained juice into a cup of your choice. Drink the juice immediately for the freshest taste. You can store leftover juice in a mason jar or other sealed container for up to 24 hours in the fridge. Adding Other Ingredients Add 1/2 cup (110 g) of chopped pineapple for a tropical twist. The pineapple will make the juice sweeter and add more vitamins and nutrients. Juice or blend chopped fresh pineapple with the celery to make this tropical variation. You can use frozen pineapple chunks or canned pineapple instead of fresh pineapple. If you use canned pineapple, you can even add a bit of the juice from the can in for extra flavor. If you're using a blender, the extra moisture can make blending easier! Put in 1/4 cup (5 g) of fresh mint leaves for a minty-fresh juice. Juice or blend the leaves with the celery to combine them and make this minty variety of celery juice. Mint also helps aid healthy digestion, which is one of the benefits that celery juice is said to have. An added bonus of fresh mint leaves is that the juice will help freshen your breath! Mix in 2  tsp (9.9 mL) of lemon juice for a celery lemonade. Stir in freshly-squeezed lemon juice to your celery juice to boost the flavor and add some vitamin C. Add more or less based on your personal tastes. You can substitute lime for lemon juice if you like. Combine the celery with 1 chopped apple to make celery-apple juice. Remove the core and chop up 1 apple of a variety of your choosing. Put the chunks through your juicer or in your blender with the celery when you are making your juice.Tip: You can combine any number of ingredients you would like to create your own celery juice recipe. Other things you can try include ginger, kale, cucumber, and carrots. Granny Smith apples are a good choice because their slightly sour flavor helps hide the bland flavor of the celery.

Something like a mason jar works best.
Making Celery Juice in a Blender Cut 2 bunches of celery stalks up into 1 in (2.5 cm) chunks.
Lay 1 bunch of celery sideways on a cutting board and cut off the leafy tops and the white bottom.
Cut the celery stalks into approximately 1 in (2.5 cm) chunks and repeat the process for another bunch of celery.
It takes twice as much celery to make a serving of celery juice in a blender than a juicer because you will be left with a lot more fiber at the end that you need to strain out.
Wash the celery pieces in a colander to clean them.
Put the chopped celery into a colander.
Hold it under running water and move the pieces around with your hand to wash any dirt and other substances off.
This is especially important if you are using non-organic celery to make sure you remove any traces of pesticides or other chemicals.
Try to use organic celery for making juice whenever possible.
Blend about 1/4 of the celery pieces until they are roughly chopped.
Place about 1/4 of the chopped celery stalks into the base of a high-speed blender and put the lid on.
Turn the blender on at medium to high speed until the celery pieces are chopped into smaller pieces and start to release liquid.
This helps the blender get going so it will be easier to blend the rest of the celery.
If you try to blend it all at once, it will be much harder to get an even, smooth consistency.
Put the rest of the pieces in and blend the celery until it is smooth.
Take the lid of the blender off and add the rest of the chopped celery on top of the celery you started to blend.

Put the lid back on and blend the celery at high speed until it is a smooth, juice-like consistency.Tip: Pour 1/4-1/2 cup (59-118 mL) of water into the blender if you are having trouble blending the celery to help it get going.
Use the push stick, if your blender has one, or another utensil to push chunks of celery down towards the blades as you blend them.
Be careful not to get the utensil caught in the blades if you are using something long enough to reach them.
Strain the celery juice through a nut milk bag.
Place a nut milk bag in a measuring cup or pitcher and pour the blended celery in.
Lift up the bag and squeeze it hard with your hands to strain all the liquid through into the container.
Discard the pulp inside the bag.
A nut milk bag is a fabric bag that is normally used for straining out the pulp of nuts to make nut milks, such as almond milk or cashew milk.
They also work perfectly for straining blended juices.
If you don’t have a nut milk bag, you can strain the juice through a fine-mesh colander or cheesecloth instead.
Keep in mind that if you use a colander you won’t be able to squeeze as much of the juice out this way, so there will be more waste.
Serve the juice right away.
Pour the strained juice into a cup of your choice.
Drink the juice immediately for the freshest taste.
You can store leftover juice in a mason jar or other sealed container for up to 24 hours in the fridge.
Adding Other Ingredients Add 1/2 cup (110 g) of chopped pineapple for a tropical twist.
The pineapple will make the juice sweeter and add more vitamins and nutrients.
Juice or blend chopped fresh pineapple with the celery to make this tropical variation.
You can use frozen pineapple chunks or canned pineapple instead of fresh pineapple.
If you use canned pineapple, you can even add a bit of the juice from the can in for extra flavor.
If you're using a blender, the extra moisture can make blending easier!
Put in 1/4 cup (5 g) of fresh mint leaves for a minty-fresh juice.
Juice or blend the leaves with the celery to combine them and make this minty variety of celery juice.
Mint also helps aid healthy digestion, which is one of the benefits that celery juice is said to have.
An added bonus of fresh mint leaves is that the juice will help freshen your breath!
Mix in 2  tsp (9.9 mL) of lemon juice for a celery lemonade.
Stir in freshly-squeezed lemon juice to your celery juice to boost the flavor and add some vitamin C. Add more or less based on your personal tastes.
You can substitute lime for lemon juice if you like.
Combine the celery with 1 chopped apple to make celery-apple juice.
Remove the core and chop up 1 apple of a variety of your choosing.

Put the chunks through your juicer or in your blender with the celery when you are making your juice.Tip: You can combine any number of ingredients you would like to create your own celery juice recipe.
Other things you can try include ginger, kale, cucumber, and carrots.
Granny Smith apples are a good choice because their slightly sour flavor helps hide the bland flavor of the celery.
